Entries.default: "I don't believe we know one another. Per complanca, leave me be."

"Oi, cap! There he be! There be Remaro, sure as my arse be blue!"

Serafen runs to meet an old, white-robed man.

"I wish you'd not come, my lad, pleased though I be to see you. Even Aeldys' anarchists spare no mercy for mutineers."

Serafen breaks away and peers up at Remaro.

"Aye, but you, a traitor? The very thought of it be ludicrous."

He spreads his open palms wide to either side.

"I can't, Blue, much as I loathe to leave. I'm dead to these waters, and they to me."

Serafen gapes and sputters before finding his response.
"What can I do for you?"
"Why would you leave the Príncipi?"
"Is it true, what you're accused of?"
"Why did you leave Fort Deadlight? You might have been safe there."
"The Príncipi have changed, and not for the better. Once we aligned behind a common purpose."

"I've not heard every charge against me, but that of mutiny? Of that charge I bear guilt."

Serafen's ears droop. He reaches for Remaro, but stops short, letting his hands fall.
"I... couldn't bear to remain, sheltered or no. It's a hopeless feeling, bearing witness to the slow decline of something I once held such pride in."

"Why? The Sorcerer were our home and kin. Were our cock-swelling pride. And you bartered it to a half-drowned old elf for a pint-bilged fucking clipper?" Staring intently on the ground at Remaro's feet, Serafen shakes, his fists balled at his sides.

"Captain Bastian had the Sorcerer slaving."

Remaro frowns at his dark, wrinkled hands, and rubs his palms together.
"Slaving? What kind of fathom-headed hornswoggle be this? The Sorcerer were my kin! They weren't slaving! I hunted slavers for the captain! We freed slaves together!"
"I meant you not to know. To keep your faith in our traditions. To remain optimistic, a bright star within the Príncipi."
"There still be pride to be had, honor too. Things be changing, sure as shit, but you can't thread them narrows if you ain't even at the wheel."
"Ac. These rheumy eyes have seen too much. Nepotism and cronyism run rampant, rotting the Príncipi from inside out."
"Sientere, Serafen. I've disappointed you. Hurt you. No words can justify my actions. I only hope you believe me - that I did what needed doing."
"Remaro, did this have something to do with your captain trafficking slaves?"
"Serafen, you've heard Remaro's confession. What would you do with him now?"
"Remaro, you're coming with us to face the judgment of the Consuaglo."
"Ne. The Consuaglo has run dry of justice. Do what you must, but I'll not return."
"Cut him loose, cap. Aye, he did the Deadfire a fine turn by sinking them slavers, but among the Consuaglo, mutiny means death, per guonfer or no."
"Cut him loose, captain. Let him hold this shit close to his bilge-rat heart for what beats be remaining it."
"We'll leave you be, Remaro."
[Attack] "You won't leave this island alive."

"Then only the thing remains, Captain Watcher. To split your bowel-sucking skull and scramble your scurvy brains for chum!"

Serafen draws his weapon.
"Corès, Serafen."
"Agracima, Watcher. The clipper will be loaded soon, and then we'll be away."
"Where do you intend to go?"
"I hope I'm wrong, if only for your sake. I don't think the Príncipi can survive as is, and I can't watch something I devoted my life to sink into ruin."

"My crew, those few souls who followed me from the Sorcerer, and I set sail for lands west. The Reach, perhaps, or the Living Lands. Perhaps we'll run trade from Aedyr or Vailia. Wherever fortune leads."
"Now we've fractured into two extremes, each wallowing in its own corruption."
"Power consolidates behind the least deserving. The Consuaglo's leadership founders, and with it, my faith."
"You're fleeing your problems."

"Belay that blarney, you old sea dog. You know good as any there ain't no faith on these waters save that you be finding for yourself." 

He flashes a crooked smirk and strikes a closed fist against his chest.
"A fine dream. I pray to Ondra that you achieve it. For me, though, the current flows but one way. A return to the Príncipi would mean my death."
"So I also believed. But Bastian sold those we saved to the Crookspur slavers. I found records of it in his quarters, almost a decade's worth. When I confronted him... it went poorly."

Sand beneath your feet, crusted and blooded, you young and small, filthy and shaking in fright, cheers from all corner - jeers, too - and the shouts of the kith before you, aumaua and thrice your height, heavy-muscle and soft fat wrapped in bright robes - don't make me go again, you plead, don't make me...
"We ship out soon. Take care of Serafen for me. He'll take care of you."
Serafen throws his arms around the man's waist, and he pats the orlan upon the head with one hand while resting the other on his shoulder. He smiles, a pensive expression that doesn't reach his eyes.

"Return with us. I'll be protecting you, and we'll be seeing to your fair judging."

With a slow shake of his head, Remaro swallows.

"Break my biscuits and call me swabby, you've gone addled in your dotage, ain't you?"
 
The orlan looks to you, lower lip twitching.
"Captain! Unsheathe that silvered tongue of yours and talk some damned sense into this old salt!"
"I know we ain't seen always eye to eyehole, but if you do anything for me ever, captain, talk some damned sense into this senile old salt!"
"Captain! Can you talk some sense into this crusty old salt?"
"But... that be the far fucking side of Eora!"
"Ac, a journey and a half to be certain."
"Fourteen years I spent swabbing them decks. Longer yet for you. Captain Bastian trusted you. I trusted you." His glare rises to meet Remaro's eyes.

"Ac, bon aimico..."

Remaro's mouth opens briefly before closing again, and he swallows.

"How can I?"

With a tired shrug, Serafen looks away.
"You're hiding something."

"Betwixt your brains and my swagger, we'll be righting the good ship Príncipi sen Patrena forthwith and be shot of these ship-squiffy doldrums."

Remaro's frown deepens as he looks away from Serafen and towards the sea.
"Ac, that I am. Many things. For many reasons. I learned long ago that it's ofttimes better to hold your tongue."
"A wise Watcher once told me that honesty always be best. I didn't believe the words at the time, but they led me right when it counted."

"The Watcher here reminded me that you and me, we be deeper than two hands on a deck. We be kin. You be the closest thing I've ever had to a father, and if you be setting sail, I'll be embarking with you."
"Magran's flaming tits, old man, you sound three-sheets sodden. Stow your self-pitying blather and answer the Watcher's flogging questions!"

"You sure bout this, Captain Watcher? Whatever he's done, you draw on my family, you be drawing on me." 

His hands move to his weapons.
"Stand down, Serafen."
"The law of the sea is clear - mutiny means death."
[Back off.] "Serafen just saved your life, Remaro."
"You don't steal from family and stay family."
[Attack] "So be it."
"All due respect, Captain Watcher, take a long fuck off a short plank."
The blue orlan winces, eyes falling to the side.
"Ac. Not for the first time, either. For all he says he owes me, I owe him in turn."
Serafen's eyes widen, then fall closed. He nods and looks to Remaro.
"Aye, cap. Looks like this nut didn't fall too far from the tree."
"You heard his reasons, cap, clear as me."
"Don't matter what he did, I can't be a party to this. Corès, Remaro. I'll be remembering you as you were."

"Corès, bon aimico."

Serafen turns away.

"How did you...?"

Remaro blinks, then shakes his head.

Serafen blinks, expression blank. His mouth opens, closes, opens again. 

His fur bristles, ears angling lower.

"Your journeys with this [player race] have changed you, Blue. You wear it well, bon aimico."

He sighs, and shakes his head sadly.
"I cannot do for you what you ask, bon aimico. Nor I can I do it to you."
Rage rushes through your blood, flushing your skin, and cold hate spirals along the length of your spine as confusion blurs your vision.

His heavy hand sends you sprawling in the sand to a chorus of jubilant applause, you bounce to your feet as the other slave boy approaches - you feel his thoughts, a tickle in the back of your mind, his fear, greater than your own, but what can you do - only one may live - you silence everything but the anger, but the hate, and it propels your snapping teeth and grasping hands, the blows light but fast, and the other youth all screams...

"Sientere, bon aimico, forgive me."

Remaro stands a bit unsteadily.
[Fight against it.]
[Let the visions come.]
You close your thoughts against the onslaught of Serafen's emotions and they break upon you, scattering.
"You okay, Serafen?"
Serafen snorts and shakes his head. Moisture matts the fur beneath his eyes.

"Corès, Serafen, bon aimico. Take this, may you have rare cause to use it."

He provides Serafen with a tightly-wrapped package.
"I hope we meet again someday, on calmer seas."
